content:
About the 4th test, with 21, which is 10101 in binary.

Three ones > Two zeros ; there are more ones than zeros, isn't it ?

According to these rules :
true -> All ones.
trueish -> More ones than zeros, or equal ones and zeros. !!!!
falsish -> More zeros than ones.
false -> All zeros.

The result expected should be : trueish.
Unfortunatly, the result expected by the test is falsish

Same problem with the 6th validator :
28 is 11100 in binary (three ones > two zeros) : should result in trueish, whereas the validator except falsish

Am I wrong ?
Kind of nasty that all the visible tests pass without padding zeroes :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear question, fun and quick solution. Good puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and great for shortest mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: the game is fun and not so obvious, tests are great, I like it

I like it for a clash. It has some place for simplifications.
In fact, only the 1s have to be counted. 0s are anyway the complement.

I first thought about using a regex to count the 1s but splitting does also the trick.

My solution in JavaScript:
const quoolean = parseInt(readline());
const n = quoolean.toString(2).split('1').length-1

console.log(n == 8 ? 'true' : 
            n == 0 ? 'false' : 
            n >= 4 ? 'trueish' : 'falsish' )
Some of your tests and validators are the same. Please revise them so that they are different. Thanks.

Hi, thanks for the feedback! 
Tests 3 and 4 test for when the binary representation is only ones or zeros. That can only happen at a single number, 255 or 0. Therefore, the test and validator need to be equal. 
I changed validator 5 to make it different from test 5.

I just got 80% because of that, since all testcases pass :/

I added the "21" testcase to prevent this ;)

:'( I just got 83% cos of this issue and hitting submit too eagerly, as 21 was the last test.
Just moved it up a bit to avoid this. :'(
